comment.body:
Note that this bug only occurs if the conditional rendering occurs on the same component as the `<slot>` element.

The bug also only occurs when the condition is only triggered through the component containing the `<slot>`.

If the condition depends on a value being passed from a parent component, the slots will render correctly.

pull_request.title: refactor: fix light dom slots for fragments
pull_request.body:
## Details
Fixes #3823

## Does this pull request introduce a breaking change?

* ✅ No, it does not introduce a breaking change.

## Does this pull request introduce an observable change?

* ⚠️ Yes, it does include an observable change.

This will allow `disconnectedCallback` to be invoked for light DOM slots, which was merged today so it shouldn't have a large impact.

issue.title: Support ARIA element reflections on `BaseBridgeElement`
issue.body:
This is a follow-up to #3693.

Currently, if you do `this.ariaLabelledByElements` inside a `LightningElement`, [you get null](https://stackblitz.com/edit/salesforce-lwc-ozokzs?file=src%2Fmain.js).

```js
renderedCallback() {
  console.log(this.ariaLabelledByElements) // always null
}
```

(Note this demo currently only works in Safari. In Chrome the feature is [behind a flag](https://chromestatus.com/feature/6244885579431936) and in Firefox it's [not implemented yet](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1859211).)

All told, we should support the following [`ARIAMixin` properties](https://w3c.github.io/aria/#ARIAMixin) on `BaseBridgeElement`:

* ariaActiveDescendantElement
* ariaControlsElements
* ariaDescribedByElements
* ariaDetailsElements
* ariaErrorMessageElements
* ariaFlowToElements
* ariaLabelledByElements
* ariaOwnsElements

We should _not_ make any attempt to polyfill anything, but we can at least unblock the APIs and return whatever the browser provides.

Note we already do support all `aria*` APIs on `LightningElement` (since it just inherits from `HTMLElement`), so e.g. `elm.ariaLabelledByElements` works correctly.

Also note this may need some feedback from Locker folks, since there is a potential for cross-shadow-root leakage here (a component can leak elements from its ancestors' shadow roots).

issue.title: Add missing ARIA attr/prop reflections

labels.name: Up for grabs
labels.description: Issues that are relatively small, self-contained, and ready for implementation

issue.body:
Looking at [the ARIAMixin spec](https://w3c.github.io/aria/#ARIAMixin) and the `aria*` props available on `Element.prototype` in Chrome, there are a few we're missing.

Missing per Chrome:

- ariaBrailleLabel
- ariaBrailleRoleDescription
- ariaDescription

Missing per the latest spec:

- ariaColIndexText
- ariaDescription
- ariaRowIndexText

Once https://github.com/salesforce/lwc/pull/3666 is released and we are out of the business of applying global polyfills, it should be safe to add these to the `LightningElement`/`BaseBridgeElement` prototypes. This will make it so that a template like:

```html
<x-cmp aria-description="foo"></x-cmp>
```

...results in the `ariaDescription` prop (not attr) being set on `x-cmp`. This is consistent with what we currently do for most ARIA props, which allows for things like overriding the `aria*` getter/setter, plus convenience accessors like `this.aria*`.

Note: per Safari we are also missing the `*Element`/`*Elements` APIs, but since these are element reflection and not string reflection, we probably shouldn't do anything with these. Also we already have our non-standard string reflection for these:

- ariaActiveDescendantElement
- ariaControlsElements
- ariaDescribedByElements
- ariaDetailsElements
- ariaErrorMessageElements
- ariaFlowToElements
- ariaLabelledByElements
- ariaOwnsElements

Missing per Chrome:

- ariaBrailleLabel
- ariaBrailleRoleDescription
- ariaDescription

Missing per the latest spec:

- ariaColIndexText
- ariaDescription
- ariaRowIndexText

Once https://github.com/salesforce/lwc/pull/3666 is released and we are out of the business of applying global polyfills, it should be safe to add these to the `LightningElement`/`BaseBridgeElement` prototypes. This will make it so that a template like:

Note: per Safari we are also missing the `*Element`/`*Elements` APIs, but since these are element reflection and not string reflection, we probably shouldn't do anything with these. Also we already have our non-standard string reflection for these:

- ariaActiveDescendantElement
- ariaControlsElements
- ariaDescribedByElements
- ariaDetailsElements
- ariaErrorMessageElements
- ariaFlowToElements
- ariaLabelledByElements
- ariaOwnsElements

pull_request.title: feat: adding missing aria attributes
pull_request.body:
## Details
Github issue link: https://github.com/salesforce/lwc/issues/3693
This PR is to add missing ARIA attributes:
1. ariaColIndexText
2. ariaRowIndexText
3. ariaDescription
4. ariaBrailleLabel
5. ariaBrailleRoleDescription

Followed Resources: https://w3c.github.io/aria/#ARIAMixin , https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Accessibility/ARIA/Attributes/aria-braillelabel, And already existing similar ARIA attributes.


## Does this pull request introduce a breaking change? 

<!--
    Any change that can cause downstream consumers to fail qualifies as a breaking change.
    
    Examples:
        - Removing the code for a deprecated API.
        - Adding a new restriction to the compiler which might result in a compilation failure for existing code.
        - Changing the return type of a function in a non-backward compatible fashion.

    Remove the incorrect item for the list. 
-->
* ✅ No, it does not introduce a breaking change.

<!-- If yes, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications. -->

## Does this pull request introduce an observable change?

<!--
    Observable changes are internal changes that can be observed by downstream consumers. 
    Such changes don't qualify as breaking changes because they don't impact any publicly defined 
    APIs.

    Examples:
        - Fixing a bug.
        - Changing the invocation timing of a callback, for a callback that has no invocation timing
          guarantee.

    Remove the incorrect item from the list. 
-->

* ⚠️ Yes, it does include an observable change.

<!-- If yes, please describe the anticipated observable changes. -->
The observable changes are only related to ARIA, hence improving accessibility.

## GUS work item
<!-- Work ID in text, if applicable. -->

issue.title: Components that do not extend LightningElement should get dev warnings for missing `@api`
issue.body:
Follow-up to https://github.com/salesforce/lwc/pull/3713 and #3758

Components that extend a non-LightningElement superclass:

```js
export default class extends CustomSuperclass {}
```

... should still get dev warnings when they declare a method that is not `@api`-annotated. (Implemented in https://github.com/salesforce/lwc/pull/3713)

This is disabled for now because it turned out to be tricky to handle superclasses that declare `@api` but whose subclasses do not.

comment.body: @mayurrkukreja We don't have a process of assigning issues, but please feel free to take this up 🙂
